author: sky.cactus
content: I would love to get some eyes and/or approvals on <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2924>.  It is a PR against 1559 that gets rid of the dual-pools and transition and instead auto-upgrades legacy transactions to 1559 transactions.  This should significantly simplify implementation and notably reduce risk (a lot of the technical risk of 1559 was in the transition period dual transaction pools).

author: sky.cactus
content: I haven't heard anyone argue *against* this, and the general sentiment seemed like everyone either agreed or was ambivalent about it so I would like to get it merged unless someone pipes up with a dissenting opinion.  I think the strongest dissenting opinion was <@!332923501079953409> who very strongly wants to see some kind of end-of-life policy (that we stick to!), but doesn't seem to care particularly what that is, and I think the legacy transaction tax that someone proposed was the best option for that (and can be in a separate EIP, and doesn't have to ship with 1559).

author: abdel.stark
content:
> What is the status of implementations btw?
<@!273808422753796097> Geth and Besu are aligned with the specification without the changes proposed by <@!301186049323958275> . So we still have 2 gas pools and a transition period. We don't use the typed transaction envelope for the encoding, we added the 2 fields (gas premium and feecap) at the end of the legacy RLP structure. And Geth has a mining issue (<@!376568077950910466> is investigating).

author: abdel.stark
content: BTW <@!301186049323958275> i am strongly against the code instead of the spec. Way less readable IMO. Code is not a spec.  And it can lead to confusion because languages don't have the same behaviour for some operations (division for example).

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Code is not a spec.
Comics on the internet disagree with this statement.  ðŸ˜‰   <https://www.commitstrip.com/en/2016/08/25/a-very-comprehensive-and-precise-spec/>

author: sky.cactus
content: The `//` is defined at the top of the specification section of the EIP I believe, specifically because its behavior is not common across languages.

author: sky.cactus
content: Are there other language idiosyncrasies that you found confusing?

author: sky.cactus
content: The latest revision also got rid of negative numbers, which further removes language specific idiosyncrasies.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree with you that using clever constructs and language specific features in specifications hurts rather than helps, though I don't agree that using some obscure specification language or homemade specification language would make the situation better.

author: sky.cactus
content: The other option is plain English, which is *notoriously* imprecise.

author: timbeiko
content: Can we just have both?

author: abdel.stark
content: I would be happy if we have both <@!301186049323958275>, so that we can choose what we are the more comfortable with

author: abdel.stark
content:
> Are there other language idiosyncrasies that you found confusing?
<@!301186049323958275> Nothing comes in mind

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Can we just have both?
<@!552133098075193354> This doubles the maintenance work (arguably more than that since maintaining the code is easier than maintaining the English), and historically when we have tried this the human readable version ends up not matching the code version which leads to more bugs.

author: sky.cactus
content: For context, what lead me to switch to a code based specification is that I was spending an inordinate amount of time trying to make changes to the specification back when it was in a homemade specification language that looks a bit like English but isn't really.  Once I switched to Python, it was far easier (despite me not actually knowing Python really), and changes after that have been *way* easier.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though... I ran into problems back when we had the dual pool thing, and that was where most of the complexity came from.  It *may* be worth another shot to see if it is still as difficult to create/maintain now that we have gotten rid of that.
